title: Shenandoah River, VA and WV
name: Shenandoah River, VA and WV
description:
Reference gauge info at the following sites:

<p>Front Royal, VA (South Fork Shenandoah): http://waterdata.usgs.gov/va/nwis/uv/?site_no=01631000&PARAmeter_cd=00065,00060,62620,00062

<p>Strasburg, VA (North Fork Shenandoah)
http://waterdata.usgs.gov/md/nwis/uv/?site_no=01634000&PARAmeter_cd=00065,00060,00062,00054

<p>Millville, WV
http://waterdata.usgs.gov/wv/nwis/uv/?site_no=01636500&PARAmeter_cd=00065,00060,62614

properties.name: 127 Bridge public access ramp
properties.description: Public access, parking for 10 vehicles, gravel boat ramp.

properties.name: Algonkian Park boat ramp ($)
properties.description: Ample parking, paved boat ramp.  $2 fee for kayaks/canoes, $5 for motorized boats.

properties.name: Artificial Whitewater Course
properties.description: While this whitewater training course is on private property, it's worth noting and stopping for a look.  It is fed by the discharge water from a PEPCO power plant.  This same discharge can create standing waves in the Potomac under normal water level conditions.

properties.name: Big Slackwater Boat Ramp
properties.description:
(Location approximate)
This popular Potomac access point has a double-wide boat ramp, parking for 50+ vehicles, picnic area and restrooms.  The scenery is great, but if you're kayaking on a nice day be ready to share the river with plenty of speed boats, water skiiers and PWC's.

properties.name: Brown's Run, Pin Oak public access
properties.description:
According to http://www.monocacycanoe.org/pan/cacapon-browns.htm

by Bing Garthright, 301-330-1225, August 30, 2004

 

The Brown’s Run access makes a good takeout for a 9 mile float from WV 127 at the Forks of the Cacapon.  To reach Browns Run, take WV 127 west to WV 29.  Turn right onto WV 29 North towards Paw Paw.  At the hamlet of Pin Oak, you turn right onto County 29-4.  There should be a sign on at the WV 29 / County 29-4 pointing towards the public river access, but sign can be hard to spot.  Less than a mile from WV 29, County 29-4 ends at a T intersection.  Turn left and go about 1.5 miles to some buildings near the river, and turn left again.  If you reach a private bridge across the Cacapon, retrace your steps back to the buildings.  The left turn near the buildings leads to a gravel lot and dirt ramp access.  Browns Run enters the Cacapon near here.  The access is also known as Pin Oak for the hamlet on WV 29.

properties.name: C&O Canal Aqueduct Ramp #2, Mouth of Monocacy
properties.description: Facilities include a comfort station, parking for vehicles with boat trailers and a paved boat ramp.

properties.name: C&O Canal Campground
properties.description: According to <u>Maryland and Delaware Canoe Trails</u> there's a campground here that you can use to take out after an Antietam trip.  Not clear what the parking and access conditions are like, or if there's a fee to use the campground.

properties.name: Capon Bridge CR15 access via Private Property
properties.description: See http://www.monocacycanoe.org/pan/cacapon-edrun.htm for access somewhere along this road.

properties.name: Capon Bridge, Flower Creations & Gifts access ($)
properties.description:
According to http://www.monocacycanoe.org/pan/cacapon-caponbridge_july05.htm :

Immediately at the west end of the bridge and BEFORE the store, turn downstream / north onto a gravel driveway.  The put-in is about 25 yards downstream, at a grassy slope.  Park vehicles on the river side of the driveway, NOT alongside the store. 

 

No advance notice is required, and you can launch / land after hours.  Your payment goes into a self-service box that’s stocked with envelopes, so you’ll need a pen along with your $5.   If you have questions, the store’s phone is 304- 856-2225.

properties.name: Clarke County public access ramp
properties.description: Parking is available for about 20 vehicles, and the ramp is paved.

properties.name: Confluence of the Potomac and Shenandoah
properties.description:
Harper's Ferry marks the confluence of two important waterways, the Potomac and the Shenandoah.  In summer months, the Shenandoah can double the water volume in the Potomac.  
Harper's Ferry itself is a historical town worth stopping at for a break to walk its reconstructed civil-war era streets.  The National Park Service has done an excellent job of restoring many of the buildings and hiring civil-war re-enactors during the tourist season.

properties.name: Crenshaw Road bridge
properties.description:
According to http://www.monocacycanoe.org/pan/goose-624.htm on 7/14/06:

by Bing Garthright, 301-330-1225, August 2004

VA 624, Crenshaw Rd, at the one-lane bridge 1.4 miles south of US 50, has fairly good access on the downstream right bank, with room to park two vehicles.  The left bank is posted and barb-wired in a hostile fashion.  The road is unpaved and little used, but adequately graded.  This bridge is 9 river miles from the Delaplane / US 17 put-in.  

There are impenetrable cattle gates hanging on the downstream side of the VA 624 bridge.  If you’re coming from upstream, get out on the right just before the bridge and carry.

PLEASE NOTE: Private owners and organizations never invite paddlers to use their land.  Most are kind enough to tolerate it.  Just as we paddle at our own risk, we use advisories, parking spaces, and access sites at our own risk.

properties.name: Dam #2 Optional route
properties.description:
Edward Gertlet recommends taking this side channel in <u>Maryland and Delaware Canoe Trails</u> as an alternate option to the main river, although the main river is also navigable here and the old Dam #2 remains are mostly submerged.
"This channel is the washed out remains of the old Patowmack Canal, part of a pre-C&O Canal navigational venture of George Washington's to bypass the Fall Line rapids.  Spiced with numerous rubbly or ledgy riffles, this passage has long delighted novice whitewater boaters.  Many say it reminds them of a bayou with gradient.  A popular practice is just to run these riffles, then ferry over to the Maryland side for a short carry up to the C&O Canal, and finally ascend the canal, a loop of a little over two miles."

properties.name: Devil's Backbone Park and Dam
properties.description: The park is pretty and would make a good place to stop for a break.  The dam is high enough to require a carry.

properties.name: Dickerson Warm Water Access
properties.description: According to <u>Maryland and Delaware Canoe Trails</u> this is a good access point to the power plant warm water discharge.  It's not clear if there is access to the Potomac from here as well.

properties.name: Edwards Ferry boat ramp
properties.description: Paved parking for a dozen cars, paved boat ramp with high water indicator.

properties.name: Evergreen Mills access (approximate location)
properties.description:
According to http://www.monocacycanoe.org/pan/goose-VA621.htm on 7/14/06:
by Bing Garthright, 301-330-1225, August 2004
A potentially easier access is on the left bank, upstream from the VA 621 bridge.  Use the dirt driveway that’s posted as “No Trespassing” by Mr. Herbert C. Bohrer of Leesburg, VA, 703-327-4265.  In a June 2004 phone conversation, Mr. Bohrer assured Bing Garthright that paddlers are welcome so long as they don’t add to the serious littering problems on that site.  If you use this access, take a trash bag and help out Mr. Bohrer.

properties.name: Fisher's Bridge access
properties.description:
According to http://www.monocacycanoe.org/pan/cacapon-fishers.htm
by Bing Garthright, 301-330-1225, August 30, 2004

 

About 10 miles downstream of Largent, WV, is Fishers Bridge, the middle of 3 WV 9 bridges over the Cacapon.  To reach the access, head north from the bridge on WV 9 and take the first left (upstream) onto Constant Run Rd.  Go exactly 0.7 miles and you’ll find space to park 2 or 3 vehicles on the right shoulder, across from the river.  (This is only 0.3 river miles upstream of Fishers Bridge.)  You could park 1 or 2 more vehicles a few hundred yards back towards WV 9.  Continuing about 0.2 miles further down Constant Run Rd away from WV 9, there is a good turn-around spot, but access and parking there is forbidden.

properties.name: Foxcroft Road access
properties.description: A very picturesque spot to put in, there is room for two or three vehicles just north of the bridge on the side of the road.  A steep but short path leads down to the water.

properties.name: Front Royal Landing
properties.description: According to http://www.shenandoah.cc/maps/north.pdf there's a takeout point here.  Not clear if it's private or if there's parking.  Need to scout out first.

properties.name: Funkstown, Oak Ridge Road access
properties.description: According to <u>Maryland and Delaware Canoe Trails</u> it sounds like there's access here.  No indication of parking or condition of the location.  Water level at Burnside Bridge should be at least 3.4' to start here.

properties.name: Great Falls - Class 5-6
properties.description: One of the best kayaking falls in the country, but best left for advanced kayakers!

properties.name: Great Falls Park boat ramp ($)
properties.description: Great Falls Park has great parking and a paved boat ramp, as well as many hiking trails and picnic spots.  This is the last takeout point before the dam and Great Falls.  A $5 fee applies for use of the boat ramp.

properties.name: Harper's Ferry Road access
properties.description: According to <u>Maryland and Delaware Canoe Trail</u> this is a good take-out point for an Antietam trip.  Not clear what the parking or access conditions are.  This could also make a good access point to the Potomac.

properties.name: Hazard - Dam
properties.description:
Takeout and portage to the right of the dam.
Note that water is recommended to be 2' minimum for kayaking between here and the Keep Loudoun Beautiful Park.  See gauge info at http://waterdata.usgs.gov/usa/nwis/uv?site_no=01644000

properties.name: Hazard - Dam #3
properties.description: Carry around on Maryland side, or by lifting over the left end of the dam if the level is low enough (according to Maryland and Delaware Canoe Trails 5.0' at Hancock, 3.7' at Shepherdstown).

properties.name: Hazard - Dam and Falls
properties.description: You don't want to go over this dam!  Take out well upstream from here.

properties.name: Indian Hollow Road, Rt 613 public access
properties.description: Public accesss somewhere around here according to http://www.shenandoah.cc/maps/north.pdf

properties.name: Karo's Public Landing
properties.description: According to http://www.shenandoah.cc/maps/north.pdf

properties.name: Keep Loudoun Beautiful Park
properties.description: There is parking for a dozen or so vehicles and a short, rocky path to the water's edge.

properties.name: Kephart Bridge Landing
properties.description:
Paved parking for a dozen vehicles and short (100 yard) walk to water.  Entrance to parking lot can be easy to miss -- look for two stone pillars between houses and a small brown sign indicating the park entrance at 43942 Riverpoint Drive.

Since Google Earth hasn't filled in all the new streets in this neighborhood, here are directions:
From Belmont Ridge Road, cross over Riverside Parkway, turn left onto Riverpoint Drive.  Keep going approximately 1 mile.  The park will be on your left at 43942 Riverpoint Drive.

properties.name: Lime Kiln Road access (approximate location)
properties.description:
According to http://www.monocacycanoe.org/pan/goose-VA733.htm on 7/14/06:

by Bing Garthright, 301-330-1225, August 2004

Route 733, noted as “close alongside on the left bank for many miles” in Corbett’s Virginia Whitewater still offers several good access points.

...The road is only 10 feet above the river, the beach is rock, the bank is graveled, the climb is easy, and you can park 4 vehicles at or near there.  It is 4.5 miles west of Rte US15, and is 50 yards east of a driveway with the address “38062 Lime Kiln Road”.

properties.name: Lock 30, Route 17 Bridge
properties.description: According to <u>Maryland and Delaware Canoe Trails</u> there is river access under this bridge on the Maryland side.  I haven't checked it out myself yet and it's not clear from this low res section of Google Earth imagery.

properties.name: Near Devil's Backbone Park access
properties.description: We put in approximately here once in a small tributary that feeds the Antietam, but it's in someone's driveway and no place to leave a vehicle. I think the Devil's Backbone park must have access downstream of the dam, but I haven't had a chance to check it out yet. The banks looked a bit high from the road. Burnside Bridge water levels should be at least 2.8' to start paddling at Devil's Backbone.

properties.name: Noland's Ferry access
properties.description: Access here, not sure of details

properties.name: Old Angler's Inn access
properties.description: A popular access point for kayakers on the lower Potomac.  A fair amount of parking place, but a bit of a carry to reach the water.

properties.name: Private property access ($)
properties.description: With a $5 fee and precise instructions, a private floating dock here can be used for kayak launches.  See http://www.monocacycanoe.org/pan/cacapon-largent.htm  for details.

properties.name: Public access about here
properties.description:
According to the WV DNR (Department of Natural Resources), there's access about 3 miles North of Capon Bridge, on CR15.  Parking for 10 vehicles and a path to the river.

See http://www.wvdnr.gov/fishing/public_access.asp?county=Hampshire&type=Public+Access+Sites&point=P35  for sketchy details.

properties.name: Rope swing!
properties.description: There's a great rope swing on a tree leaning out over the water from the right bank right about here.  Take a break from paddling and climb out on this twenty-foot high limb for an adrenaline rush and a quick dip!

properties.name: Route 15 Bridge, Point of Rocks
properties.description: The Maryland side of the Route 15 Bridge has lots of parking space and a paved boat ramp with high water indicators.  This section of the Potomac has beautiful scenery, and as nearly all the Potomac River access points in Maryland this spot is right on the scenic C&O Canal.  The rail road tracks also go through a tunnel here, fun for kids to watch.

properties.name: Route 15 Bridge, VA side
properties.description: A small picnic area with more parking is located directly across the Potomac from the Point of Rocks boat ramp.  This area doesn't have a boat ramp as far as I can remember from the last time I was there, but kayaks can easily be carried to the river's edge a few yards from the parking lot, much closer of a walk than when parking on the MD side.

properties.name: Route 15 bridge
properties.description: According to http://www.monocacycanoe.org/pan/goose-US15.htm there is access to Goose Creek here, including room for about six cars on the shoulder of the road.  I haven't checked it out myself yet.

properties.name: Route 34 bridge
properties.description: Space for a couple cars to park, and a rough path 20 yards or so to the river down a short incline. Pull off to the south on the east side of the bridge, parking area is slightly hidden from road. Burnside Bridge water levels should be at least 2.6' to start paddling at Route 34 bridge.

properties.name: Route 340 bridge
properties.description: While there's limited parking available (2 or 3 vehicles max), this is a common take-out point for organized boaters or tubers and has room for buses to pick up groups.  Access to the Potomac is via a steep climb down and a couple minutes walk -- not easy carrying a kayak and gear up on your own, but possible.

properties.name: Route 50 bridge
properties.description: Parking for a dozen cars, paved boat ramp

properties.name: Route 7 bridge
properties.description: Access via River Rd on the east side of the bridge.  Gravel parking lot for 20+ vehicles, and a paved boat ramp.

properties.name: Skip's Landing
properties.description: Public access, but "nasty, vertical landing" according to http://www.shenandoah.cc/maps/north.pdf

properties.name: State Park access
properties.description: Access according to http://www.shenandoah.cc/maps/north.pdf.  Also see http://www.state.va.us/dcr/parks/andygues.htm for park information.

properties.name: Swain's Lock access
properties.description: I haven't been here yet, but it looks like there's at least access to the C&O Canal, and possibly access to the Potomac via a short walk.

properties.name: The Needles, Class 2+
properties.description: Under normal water flow this section of staircase rapids is considered Class 2. Under higher water levels the flow is strong and novices would be advised to avoid it. Minimum water level should be 2.8' at Hancock, 1.8' at Shepherdstown. Levels over 5' at Hancock should be considered high water conditions.

properties.name: USGS Gauge
properties.description: http://waterdata.usgs.gov/va/nwis/uv/?site_no=01644000&PARAmeter_cd=00065,00060,62620,00062

properties.description: http://waterdata.usgs.gov/wv/nwis/uv/?site_no=01611500&PARAmeter_cd=00065,00060,62614

properties.name: USGS Gauge Potomac River at Hancock, MD
properties.description: http://waterdata.usgs.gov/md/nwis/uv/?site_no=01613000&PARAmeter_cd=00065,00060,00062,00054

properties.name: USGS Gauge Potomac River at Harper's Ferry
properties.description: http://waterdata.usgs.gov/md/nwis/uv/?site_no=01620000&PARAmeter_cd=00065,00060,00062,00054

properties.name: USGS Gauge at Millville, WV
properties.description: http://waterdata.usgs.gov/wv/nwis/uv/?site_no=01636500&PARAmeter_cd=00065,00060,62614

properties.name: USGS Gauge, NF Shenandoah near Strasburg, VA
properties.description: http://waterdata.usgs.gov/md/nwis/uv/?site_no=01634000&PARAmeter_cd=00065,00060,00062,00054

properties.name: USGS Gauge, Potomac River Little Falls Pump Station
properties.description: http://waterdata.usgs.gov/md/nwis/uv/?site_no=01646500&PARAmeter_cd=00065,00060,00062,00054

properties.name: USGS Gauge, Potomac River at Pawpaw, WV
properties.description: http://waterdata.usgs.gov/md/nwis/uv/?site_no=01610000&PARAmeter_cd=00065,00060,00062,00054

properties.name: USGS Gauge, Potomac River at Point of Rocks
properties.description: http://waterdata.usgs.gov/md/nwis/uv/?site_no=01638500&PARAmeter_cd=00065,00060,00062,00054

properties.name: USGS Gauge, SF Shenandoah at Front Royal
properties.description: http://waterdata.usgs.gov/md/nwis/uv/?site_no=01631000&PARAmeter_cd=00065,00060,00062,00054

properties.name: Violettes Lock
properties.description: Violettes Lock is a great access point to the Potomac or to this watered section of the C&O Canal.  One popular practice is to ferry to the Virginia side of the Potomac, run the old Patowmack Canal, then ferry back to the Maryland side for a short carry up to the C&O Canal, and finally ascend the canal back to this point, a loop of a little over two miles.

properties.name: Watermelon Park
properties.description: Watermelon park is a campground right on the Shenandoah.  I've never tried putting a boat in here but I think they allow it for a small fee if you're not camping here.  However, there's a free public boat ramp just a couple miles west.  The campground also rent boats.  Their website is at http://www.watermelonpark.com/

properties.name: Watson Road access (approximate location)
properties.description:
According to http://www.monocacycanoe.org/pan/goose-VA621.htm on 7/14/06:

by Bing Garthright, 301-330-1225, August 2004

At the south (right bank) end of the bridge, turn onto Watson Road, VA 860.  About 20 yards from the turn, there is parking for at least 4 cars.  Walk over a high bank and down a bare dirt path to a mud and rock beach.  The carry is about 60 yards and fairly steep.  As of June 2004, this area was not posted.

properties.name: White's Ferry boat ramp ($)
properties.description: This is a great spot to end a kayak outing with a picnic, although the owners of this property charge fees for nearly everything. Be prepared for a boat ramp fee and a picnic table fee. Parking was free last time I was there. The location is picturesque and historical, and the ferry makes for a fun diversion as well. A small store supplies the basics of sandwiches, drinks, maps, etc. Canoe rental is available.

properties.name: Whitehorse Rapids, Class 2
properties.description: Whitehorse Rapids is a fun class 2 rapids popular with novice kayakers, the second set of rapids in this section if you're starting at Harper's Ferry.  There is nearly always enough water to pass through on the Maryland side.
